summary: ECoV belongs to the subfamily Orthocoronavirinae of the order Nidovirales. they are classified into four genera (alpha-, beta-, gamma- and deltacoronavirus) they infect both mammalian and avian hosts. ECoV was isolated from a two-week-old diarrheic foal in 1999. real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR) methods have been established. ECoV viral nucleic acid is generally only detectable by qPCR within a limited timeframe of 3–9 days post infection. serological assays can be used to support diagnosis of a clinical ECoV infection by showing seroconversion or a significant increase in antibody titer in paired serum samples. the N-terminal S1 subunit is responsible for receptor binding, while the C-terminal S2 subunit mediates membrane fusion. the S1 subunit is the most variable immunogenic antigen among coronaviruses, and therefore it is an ideal candidate for the detection of coV species-specific antibodies. the aim of the study was to develop and validate an ELISA method for the detection of specific antibodies to ECoV. 81 21 25.90 E WNV surveillance 2015 The Netherlands 176 145 82.40 F EIA surveillance 2015 The ECoV S1 is a highly suitable antigen for the detection of antibodies against ECoV. dELISA is a useful diagnostic test for the demonstration of a potential ECoV outbreak. results showed that the overall seroprevalence in the different cohorts tested is 25.9%–82.8%. a lower percentage (9.6%) of positive animals was found in another ECoV seroprevalence study conducted in the USA [33] study used negative qRT-PCR and absence of clinical signs as criteria to define horses as ECoV negative. in the group of young horses, the lowest seroprevalence was found. young horses may initially be protected against ECoV by maternal antibodies. risk of becoming infected increases with age. we developed a high-throughput, reliable and specific ELISA method to study humoral immune responses in horses against ECoV. with this method, we are able to perform the serodiagnosis of ECoV infection and assess the seroprevalence within horse populations.
